ygData.msgSnippet: Right...but our goal is not simply to solve Tic-Tac-Toe (we can hard code a perfect player in pretty short order). Our long-term goal is to create a strong

Right...but our goal is not simply to solve Tic-Tac-Toe (we can hard 
code a perfect player in pretty short order).

Our long-term goal is to create a strong 19x19 Go player, and we want 
to use TTT as a testing ground for methods that are going to scale up 
to larger, more complex domains.  

The approach of using ANNs as static board evaluators to assess the 
quality of board states along the nodes of a MinMax search does not 
scale up well.

Same thing with 15x15 Gomoku.  The game has already been solved, but 
if a version of NEAT can be applied to evolved neural networks that 
can play a strong game of 15x15 Gomoku, we will have learned a great 
deal about how to approach higher input/output domains.

Derek

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Chris Christenson <cc57@t...> wrote:
> Ok... but, you were talking about tic tac toe
> 
> -----Original Message-----
> From: Derek James [mailto:blue5432@y...] 
> Sent: Friday, January 30, 2004 1:33 PM
> To: neat@yahoogroups.com
> Subject: RE: [neat] Applying NEAT to Tic-Tac-Toe
> 
> --- Chris Christenson <cc57@t...> wrote:
> > Maybe I am off-base here, but why don't you use a
> > neural network to act
> > as the evaluation function in conjunction with a
> > MinMax.  Therefore,
> > outputting one number and forgetting about learning
> > how to play the game
> > and make legal moves etc.
> 
> This works for game domains with a managable branching
> factor (e.g., Checkers), where there are a relatively
> small number of potential moves on any given turn.
> 
> But a MinMax search is not going to work with games
> with enormous branching factors (like 19x19 Go, which
> has 361 possible moves on the first turn, 360 on the
> next, and so on).  
> 
> And incidentally, neither in Joseph's project or our
> research are we evolving networks that learn to make
> legal moves (illegal moves are simply ignored).
> 
> Derek
>
